name: TheAtlantic
text: Populism won’t be killed off by the pandemic. To the contrary, it flourishes in crises, writes @YasmeenSerhan: https://t.co/a5zTlYmyaW

name: TheAtlantic
text: At a time when in-person social interaction is so limited, podcasts can help bring chatter, and new voices, back into our lives and homes. The latest Atlantic Daily, from @mimbsy: https://t.co/FxtUytlAoJ

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Officials have given families and teachers vague assurances and clichéd promises, but few concrete plans and steps. Schools are not yet safe enough for us—or the students—to return," Katie Moylan and David Schepard write: https://t.co/2CLSIWnM5v

name: TheAtlantic
text: Mud is so abundant that most of us hardly think about it. But for most of Earth's history, that wasn't the case, writes @LauraPoppick. https://t.co/iLl64xBX0Q

name: TheAtlantic
text: Trump "embraces rural areas, where some of his most fervent defenders live. But time and time again, he and his administration show that they don’t care about the people who live here," @silasdhouse writes: https://t.co/0aiobX5eY5

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @YasmeenSerhan: “The pandemic has enabled populists to do what they do best: campaign against those who disagree with them, peddle their own version of the facts, and advance conspiratorial thinking over scientific opinion.” https://t.co/iPb6vFkS1D

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: What do you do when you’re being ordered to stay home and ordered to evacuate at the same time? @jdkstern13’s latest: https://t.co/JkGA2af4pD

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @YasmeenSerhan: Many things have been lost to the coronavirus, but populism is unlikely to be one of them. 

My latest: 
https://t.co/iPb6vFkS1D

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdamHSays: "Consider the emotional maturity it takes at Brayden’s age to talk about his personal struggle—especially when that personal struggle is talking" Read @JohnGHendy: https://t.co/icUI1NVmJC

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: "At the heart of the turmoil at the Postal Service is not one crisis of confidence but two." https://t.co/0STONbmjLd

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Biden seemed stiff during earlier appearances this week, but anyone who watched his acceptance speech saw a far more engaged and coherent speaker than Trump," writes @GrahamDavidA: https://t.co/1ixCpzZMJS

name: TheAtlantic
text: One disaster is bad. Two is exponentially worse. Now, @jdkstern13 reports, California is learning just how much: https://t.co/SH7yYEbyWv

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Officials have given families and teachers vague assurances and clichéd promises, but few concrete plans and steps. Schools are not yet safe enough for us—or the students—to return," Katie Moylan and David Schepard write: https://t.co/ke58kIpviL

name: TheAtlantic
text: Joe Biden is the retail campaigner who can't run a retail campaign. He's not happy about it, @IsaacDovere reports from Wilmington, Delaware: https://t.co/ArZWkucsRX

name: TheAtlantic
text: Works by Martin Luther King Jr., political speechwriters, David Sedaris, and more shed light on the art of public speaking in this week's #TheAtlanticBooksBriefing. From @cray_kate: https://t.co/v2dMsCeuxI

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @errolmorris: New article in The Atlantic, https://t.co/L5FJf9oJin

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: To presume that COVID-19 can’t resurge in New York City is "reckless beyond belief." https://t.co/YuI0yz1e9v

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @edyong209: "We should not think of the next year or two as the start of a decade or more of incremental progress. We should think of the next year or two as all the time we have, and a last chance to get it right." 

Incredible piece by psych prof @jaricheson.

https://t.co/AAiEeu2ggY

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: Seeing things through @errolmorris's eyes is always revealing. In this case, it's scary, too.  https://t.co/3RIXfliUdR

name: TheAtlantic
text: "The details in the 24-page indictment describe a scam that was almost comically flagrant," @russellberman reports: https://t.co/La0Jt1OCnn
